Alabama.possessionLimits: Medical patients can possess amount prescribed by certified physician
Alabama.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician certification
Alabama.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Alabama.description: Alabama legalized medical marijuana in 2021 through the Darren Wesley 'Ato' Hall Compassion Act. The program became operational in 2024 with licensed dispensaries opening across the state.

Alaska.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 4 ounces at home
Alaska.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Alaska.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public spaces or federally-owned land
Alaska.description: Alaska was an early adopter of medical cannabis in 1998 and legalized recreational use in 2014, becoming the third state to do so. The state allows home cultivation for both medical and recreational users.

Arkansas.possessionLimits: Up to 2.5 ounces with valid medical card
Arkansas.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Arkansas.description: Arkansas voters approved medical marijuana through Amendment 98 in 2016. Recreational marijuana remains illegal, with a ballot measure failing in 2022.

Arizona.purchaseLimits: 1 ounce flower, 5 grams concentrate per transaction
Arizona.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Arizona.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public spaces and vehicles
Arizona.description: Arizona launched its medical program in 2010 and voters approved Proposition 207 to legalize recreational cannabis in 2020. The state has a robust market with both medical and recreational dispensaries statewide.

California.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 8 ounces at home
California.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
California.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and within 1000 feet of schools
California.description: California was the first state to legalize medical marijuana with Proposition 215 in 1996. Recreational cannabis became legal in 2018 following voter approval of Proposition 64. The state has the largest cannabis market in the nation.

Colorado.purchaseLimits: 1 ounce flower, 8 grams concentrate (residents), 0.25 oz flower (non-residents)
Colorado.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 2 ounces at home
Colorado.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Colorado.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and federal lands
Colorado.description: Colorado was a pioneer in cannabis legalization, approving medical use in 2000 and becoming one of the first states to legalize recreational cannabis in 2012 with Amendment 64. The state's mature market serves as a model for other states.

Connecticut.possessionLimits: 1.5 ounces outside home, 5 ounces at home
Connecticut.homegrowLimit: 3 mature and 3 immature plants per person, 6 mature and 6 immature per household
Connecticut.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Connecticut.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public spaces and vehicles
Connecticut.description: Connecticut legalized medical cannabis in 2012 and recreational use in 2021. Retail sales began in January 2023, with home cultivation allowed starting in October 2023.

Delaware.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Delaware.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public spaces
Delaware.description: Delaware established its medical marijuana program in 2011 and legalized recreational possession in April 2023. However, retail sales infrastructure is still being developed.

Florida.purchaseLimits: 2.5 ounces flower per 35-day period, unlimited smokable products
Florida.possessionLimits: Up to 4 ounces with valid medical card
Florida.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician certification
Florida.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Florida.description: Florida voters approved Amendment 2 in 2016, establishing a comprehensive medical marijuana program. The state has one of the largest medical cannabis markets in the U.S. A recreational ballot measure failed in November 2024.

Hawaii.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Hawaii.description: Hawaii was the first state to legalize medical marijuana through the legislature rather than a ballot initiative in 2000. Recreational cannabis remains illegal, though decriminalized in small amounts.

Illinois.possessionLimits: 30 grams flower for residents, 15 grams for non-residents
Illinois.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Illinois.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public view and vehicles
Illinois.description: Illinois legalized medical cannabis in 2013 and became the 11th state to legalize recreational use in 2019. The state prioritizes social equity in licensing and expungement of past convictions.

Kentucky.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician certification
Kentucky.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Kentucky.description: Kentucky legalized medical cannabis in 2023 through Senate Bill 47. The program officially launched on January 1, 2025, making it one of the newest medical marijuana states. Dispensaries are beginning to open across the Commonwealth.

Louisiana.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Louisiana.description: Louisiana legalized medical marijuana in 2015, but the program didn't become operational until 2019. The state has expanded qualifying conditions over time and now allows smokable flower products.

Maine.homegrowLimit: 3 mature plants, 12 immature plants, unlimited seedlings
Maine.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Maine.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and vehicles
Maine.description: Maine legalized medical marijuana in 1999 and recreational use in 2016. The state maintains separate medical and recreational programs, with home cultivation permitted for both.

Maryland.possessionLimits: 1.5 ounces flower, up to 12 grams concentrate
Maryland.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Maryland.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public spaces
Maryland.description: Maryland established medical cannabis in 2014 and voters approved recreational legalization in 2022. Sales began in July 2023, with existing medical dispensaries able to serve both markets.

Massachusetts.purchaseLimits: 1 ounce flower, 5 grams concentrate per transaction
Massachusetts.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 10 ounces at home
Massachusetts.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Massachusetts.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and federally-owned property
Massachusetts.description: Massachusetts voters approved medical cannabis in 2012 and recreational use in 2016. The state has a thriving cannabis industry with numerous dispensaries throughout the Commonwealth.

Michigan.purchaseLimits: 2.5 ounces flower, 15 grams concentrate per transaction
Michigan.possessionLimits: 2.5 ounces in public, up to 10 ounces at home
Michigan.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Michigan.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public view
Michigan.description: Michigan legalized medical marijuana in 2008 and recreational use in 2018 through Proposal 1. The state has experienced rapid market growth with hundreds of licensed dispensaries.

Minnesota.purchaseLimits: 2 ounces flower, 8 grams concentrate (when sales begin)
Minnesota.possessionLimits: 2 ounces in public, 2 pounds at home
Minnesota.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Minnesota.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Minnesota.description: Minnesota established medical cannabis in 2014 and legalized recreational use in May 2023. The state is developing its retail infrastructure, with sales expected to begin in 2025.

Mississippi.purchaseLimits: 3.5 grams per day, up to 3 ounces per month
Mississippi.possessionLimits: Up to 3.5 grams per day with valid medical card
Mississippi.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician certification
Mississippi.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Mississippi.description: Mississippi voters approved medical marijuana through Initiative 65 in 2020, but it was struck down by the state Supreme Court. The legislature passed a new medical program in 2022, which became operational in late 2023.

Missouri.purchaseLimits: 3 ounces per day for recreational, 4 ounces per 30 days for medical
Missouri.homegrowLimit: 6 flowering plants per person, 12 per household (recreational); 6 flowering per patient (medical)
Missouri.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician certification for medical
Missouri.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Missouri.description: Missouri voters approved medical marijuana in 2018 through Amendment 2 and recreational use in 2022 through Amendment 3. Existing medical dispensaries were able to begin recreational sales in February 2023.

Montana.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, 2 ounces at home
Montana.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Montana.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and on federal land
Montana.description: Montana approved medical cannabis in 2004 and voters legalized recreational use in 2020 through Initiative 190. The state's cannabis program includes both retail sales and home cultivation.

Nevada.homegrowLimit: 6 plants per person, 12 per household (only if 25+ miles from dispensary)
Nevada.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Nevada.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in casinos, hotels, and public spaces
Nevada.description: Nevada voters approved medical marijuana in 2000 and recreational use in 2016. The state has a thriving cannabis industry, particularly in Las Vegas and Reno, with 24/7 dispensary operations.

New Hampshire.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
New Hampshire.description: New Hampshire established its medical cannabis program in 2013. The state has decriminalized small amounts of marijuana but has not legalized recreational use. Multiple legalization bills have been proposed but not yet passed.

New Jersey.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
New Jersey.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and vehicles
New Jersey.description: New Jersey launched medical marijuana in 2010 and voters approved recreational legalization in 2020. Sales began in April 2022, with the state maintaining strict regulations on the industry.

New Mexico.homegrowLimit: 6 mature plants, 6 immature plants per person, 12 mature per household
New Mexico.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician certification for medical
New Mexico.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
New Mexico.description: New Mexico established medical cannabis in 2007 and legalized recreational use in 2021 through the Cannabis Regulation Act. The state prioritizes social equity and local control in licensing.

New York.possessionLimits: 3 ounces in public, up to 5 pounds at home
New York.homegrowLimit: 3 mature and 3 immature plants per person, 6 mature and 6 immature per household
New York.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician certification for medical
New York.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited where tobacco smoking is prohibited
New York.description: New York legalized medical cannabis in 2014 and recreational use in 2021 through the Marihuana Regulation and Taxation Act (MRTA). The state prioritizes social equity licensing and has rapidly expanded its retail market.

North Dakota.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician certification
North Dakota.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
North Dakota.description: North Dakota voters approved medical marijuana through Measure 5 in 2016. Recreational cannabis initiatives have failed multiple times, most recently in November 2024.

Ohio.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Ohio.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Ohio.description: Ohio established medical cannabis in 2016 and voters approved Issue 2 in November 2023 to legalize recreational use. The state began recreational sales in summer 2024, with existing medical dispensaries able to serve both markets.

Oklahoma.purchaseLimits: 3 ounces flower, 1 ounce concentrate, 72 ounces edibles
Oklahoma.possessionLimits: 3 ounces flower, 1 ounce concentrate, 72 ounces edibles
Oklahoma.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
qualifyingConditions: Any condition for which a physician determines medical marijuana could be beneficial
Oklahoma.description: Oklahoma voters approved medical marijuana through State Question 788 in 2018. The state has one of the most lenient medical programs, with physicians having broad discretion in recommending cannabis. A recreational ballot measure failed in March 2023.

Oregon.purchaseLimits: 1 ounce flower, 5 grams concentrate per transaction (recreational), higher limits for medical
Oregon.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 8 ounces at home
Oregon.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Oregon.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Oregon.description: Oregon was an early adopter of medical cannabis in 1998 and legalized recreational use in 2014 through Measure 91. The state has a mature, competitive cannabis market with numerous retail locations.

Pennsylvania.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying serious medical condition
Pennsylvania.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
Pennsylvania.description: Pennsylvania legalized medical marijuana in 2016 through the Medical Marijuana Act. The state has a large medical program with dispensaries throughout the Commonwealth. Recreational legalization efforts continue but have not yet passed.

Rhode Island.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 10 ounces at home
Rhode Island.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Rhode Island.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public and vehicles
Rhode Island.description: Rhode Island established medical cannabis in 2006 and legalized recreational use in May 2022. Sales began in December 2022, making it the 19th state with legal recreational cannabis.

South Dakota.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying debilitating medical condition
South Dakota.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
South Dakota.description: South Dakota voters approved medical marijuana through Amendment A in 2020, though the recreational portion was struck down. The medical program launched in 2021. Recreational initiatives have failed in subsequent elections, most recently in November 2024.

Utah.purchaseLimits: 113 grams unprocessed cannabis (or equivalent) per 30 days
Utah.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have qualifying condition and physician recommendation
Utah.consumptionRules: Private property only, smoking prohibited (vaping, edibles, topicals allowed)
Utah.description: Utah voters approved Proposition 2 in 2018 to establish a medical marijuana program, which the legislature subsequently modified. The state prohibits smoking but allows vaping, edibles, and topicals.

Vermont.possessionLimits: 1 ounce in public, up to 2 ounces at home
Vermont.homegrowLimit: 2 mature plants, 4 immature plants per household
Vermont.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Vermont.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Vermont.description: Vermont legalized medical cannabis in 2004 and became the first state to legalize recreational cannabis through the legislature (rather than ballot initiative) in 2018. Retail sales began in October 2022.

Virginia.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician certification for medical
Virginia.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public
Virginia.description: Virginia legalized medical cannabis in 2020 and recreational possession and home cultivation in 2021. However, the state has delayed implementing retail sales, with the market structure still under development.

Washington.purchaseLimits: 1 ounce flower, 7 grams concentrate, 72 ounces edibles in liquid form
Washington.homegrowLimit: Medical patients only: up to 6 plants with authorization
Washington.ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician authorization for medical
Washington.consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited in public view
Washington.description: Washington voters approved medical marijuana in 1998 and became one of the first states to legalize recreational cannabis in 2012 with Initiative 502. The state has merged its medical and recreational systems into a unified market.

Washington D.C..ageRequirement: 21+ for recreational, any age with physician recommendation for medical
Washington D.C..consumptionRules: Private property only, prohibited on federal land and in public
Washington D.C..description: Washington D.C. legalized medical marijuana in 2010 and voters approved recreational legalization in 2014 through Initiative 71. However, congressional restrictions prevent the establishment of recreational sales, though gifting is permitted. Medical dispensaries operate normally.

West Virginia.ageRequirement: Medical: Must have serious medical condition certified by physician
West Virginia.consumptionRules: Private property only, not in public or vehicles
West Virginia.description: West Virginia legalized medical marijuana in 2017 through the Medical Cannabis Act. The program became operational in 2019 with dispensaries opening across the state. Smoking is prohibited; only vaping, oils, pills, topicals, and tinctures are allowed.
